Golden Gate Bridge

About

Golden Gate Bridge

Nested in one of the most culturally diverse cities in the United States is the stunning, architectural marvel, known as the Golden Gate Bridge.

About

Golden Gate Bridge

Nested in one of the most culturally diverse cities in the United States is the stunning, architectural marvel, known as the Golden Gate Bridge.


History

Construction began to build the bridge on January 5, 1933. The plan was to create a bridge that would span connect the San Francisco Peninsula and the southern end of Marin County.

The two key players in accomplishing the task were San Francisco's city engineer, Michael M. O'Shaughnessy and engineer and poet Joseph Strauss. They projected a cost of $25-$30 million dollars; it was no surprise that they were faced with overwhelming opposition from a variety of people. If it weren't for Bank of America buying the project, the funds may have never been secured.

The Golden Gate Bridge officially opened on May 27, 1937, the longest bridge span in the world at the time. The first public crossing had taken place the day before, when 200,000 people walked, ran and even roller skated over the new bridge.

The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the most iconic and recognizable landmarks and symbolizes San Francisco characterized by its tall towers and famous red paint.

Info

Visit

The Bridge's Welcome Center offers merchandise and historical information. Open daily from 9am to 6pm, the Welcome Center dedicated to telling the stories of the Golden Gate Bridge.

Tours

If you're interested in the history of the Golden Gate Bridge, twice-weekly (Thursdays and Sundays) free walking Bridge tours are offered by San Francisco City Guides

Hike

Both ends of the Bridge touch the Golden Gate National Recreation Area. Enjoy picturesque trails and vista points in one of the world's largest national parks in an urban area.
